natural problem: Of the numbers 1, 2, 3, ..., 15, which number has the greatest number of divisors (the dots mean that we are including all the integers between 1 and 15)?
natural solution: To find the number of divisors an integer has, we can count the number of positive divisors and double the result. For example, the positive divisors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4 while the set of all divisors of 4 is $\{-1,-2,-4,1,2,4\}$.
So the number with the most divisors will be the same as the number with the most positive divisors.

We can find the number of divisors of an integer by finding the divisors in pairs. For example, to find the divisors of 15, we begin by listing \[ 1, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, \ldots, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 15.

\]Fifteen is not divisible by 2, so we skip to 3 and find $3\cdot 5 = 15$, so we fill in 3 and 5. Three and 5 are "buddies," since they multiply to give 15. Our list becomes \[ 1, 3, \underline{\hphantom{3}},\ldots \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 5, 15.
\]Since 15 is not divisible by 4, we are done (since 5 is the next number and we already have 5 on the list).

So the total list of divisors is \[ 1, 3, 5, 15. \]Since the numbers less than 15 are small, we can easily apply this process to all the numbers from 1 to 15. Here is a table showing how many factors each number has: \begin{tabular}{c|c}

number & how many factors \\ \hline 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \\ 7 & 2 \\ 8 & 4 \\ 9 & 3 \\ 10 & 4 \\ 11 & 2 \\ 12 & 6 \\ 13 & 2 \\ 14 & 4 \\ 15 & 4 \end{tabular}We see that $\boxed{12}$ has the most factors.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {1..15}"
shows  "Max {card {d. d dvd n | n \<in> {1..15}}} = 12"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the numbers 1, 2, 3, ..., 15, which number has the greatest number of divisors (the dots mean that we are including all the integers between 1 and 15)? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 To find the number of divisors an integer has, we can count the number of positive divisors and double the result. For example, the positive divisors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4 while the set of all divisors of 4 is $\{-1,-2,-4,1,2,4\}$.
 So the number with the most divisors will be the same as the number with the most positive divisors.
 We can find the number of divisors of an integer by finding the divisors in pairs. For example, to find the divisors of 15, we begin by listing \[ 1, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, \ldots, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 15.
 \]Fifteen is not divisible by 2, so we skip to 3 and find $3\cdot 5 = 15$, so we fill in 3 and 5. Three and 5 are "buddies," since they multiply to give 15. Our list becomes \[ 1, 3, \underline{\hphantom{3}},\ldots \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 5, 15.
 \]Since 15 is not divisible by 4, we are done (since 5 is the next number and we already have 5 on the list).
 So the total list of divisors is \[ 1, 3, 5, 15. \]Since the numbers less than 15 are small, we can easily apply this process to all the numbers from 1 to 15. Here is a table showing how many factors each number has: \begin{tabular}{c|c}
 number & how many factors \\ \hline 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \\ 7 & 2 \\ 8 & 4 \\ 9 & 3 \\ 10 & 4 \\ 11 & 2 \\ 12 & 6 \\ 13 & 2 \\ 14 & 4 \\ 15 & 4 \end{tabular}We see that $\boxed{12}$ has the most factors.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {1..15}"
shows  "Max {card {d. d dvd n | n \<in> {1..15}}} = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the maximum number of divisors that a natural number between 1 and 15 (inclusive) can have. The final answer is 12.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {1..15}"
shows  "n with greatest number of divisors = 12"
a_1.formal solution:

 \]Fifteen is not divisible by 2, so we skip to 3 and find $3\cdot 5 = 15$, so we fill in 3 and 5. Three and 5 are "buddies," since they multiply to give 15. Our list becomes \[ 1, 3, \underline{\hphantom{3}},\ldots \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 5, 15.

 number & how many factors \\ \hline 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \\ 7 & 2 \\ 8 & 4 \\ 9 & 3 \\ 10 & 4 \\ 11 & 2 \\ 12 & 6 \\ 13 & 2 \\ 14 & 4 \\ 15 & 4 \end{tabular}We see that $\boxed{12}$ has the most factors.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {1..15}"
shows  "n with greatest number of divisors = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the number between 1 and 15, inclusive, that has the greatest number of divisors. The final answer is 12.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..15}. f n = card {d. d dvd n}"
shows  "GREATEST n. f n = 12"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the numbers 1, 2, 3, ..., 15, which number has the greatest number of divisors (the dots mean that we are including all the integers between 1 and 15)? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 To find the number of divisors an integer has, we can count the number of positive divisors and double the result. For example, the positive divisors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4 while the set of all divisors of 4 is $\{-1,-2,-4,1,2,4\}$.
 So the number with the most divisors will be the same as the number with the most positive divisors.
 We can find the number of divisors of an integer by finding the divisors in pairs. For example, to find the divisors of 15, we begin by listing \[ 1, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, \ldots, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 15.
 \]Fifteen is not divisible by 2, so we skip to 3 and find $3\cdot 5 = 15$, so we fill in 3 and 5. Three and 5 are "buddies," since they multiply to give 15. Our list becomes \[ 1, 3, \underline{\hphantom{3}},\ldots \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 5, 15.
 \]Since 15 is not divisible by 4, we are done (since 5 is the next number and we already have 5 on the list).
 So the total list of divisors is \[ 1, 3, 5, 15. \]Since the numbers less than 15 are small, we can easily apply this process to all the numbers from 1 to 15. Here is a table showing how many factors each number has: \begin{tabular}{c|c}
 number & how many factors \\ \hline 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \\ 7 & 2 \\ 8 & 4 \\ 9 & 3 \\ 10 & 4 \\ 11 & 2 \\ 12 & 6 \\ 13 & 2 \\ 14 & 4 \\ 15 & 4 \end{tabular}We see that $\boxed{12}$ has the most factors.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..15}. f n = card {d. d dvd n}"
shows  "GREATEST n. f n = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the largest natural number less than or equal to 15, for which the number of its divisors is equal to 12.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 15 \<longrightarrow> n i = card {d. d dvd i}"
shows  "n 12 = Max (n ` {1..15})"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the numbers 1, 2, 3, ..., 15, which number has the greatest number of divisors (the dots mean that we are including all the integers between 1 and 15)? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 To find the number of divisors an integer has, we can count the number of positive divisors and double the result. For example, the positive divisors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4 while the set of all divisors of 4 is $\{-1,-2,-4,1,2,4\}$.
 So the number with the most divisors will be the same as the number with the most positive divisors.
 We can find the number of divisors of an integer by finding the divisors in pairs. For example, to find the divisors of 15, we begin by listing \[ 1, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, \ldots, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 15.
 \]Fifteen is not divisible by 2, so we skip to 3 and find $3\cdot 5 = 15$, so we fill in 3 and 5. Three and 5 are "buddies," since they multiply to give 15. Our list becomes \[ 1, 3, \underline{\hphantom{3}},\ldots \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 5, 15.
 \]Since 15 is not divisible by 4, we are done (since 5 is the next number and we already have 5 on the list).
 So the total list of divisors is \[ 1, 3, 5, 15. \]Since the numbers less than 15 are small, we can easily apply this process to all the numbers from 1 to 15. Here is a table showing how many factors each number has: \begin{tabular}{c|c}
 number & how many factors \\ \hline 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \\ 7 & 2 \\ 8 & 4 \\ 9 & 3 \\ 10 & 4 \\ 11 & 2 \\ 12 & 6 \\ 13 & 2 \\ 14 & 4 \\ 15 & 4 \end{tabular}We see that $\boxed{12}$ has the most factors.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 15 \<longrightarrow> n i = card {d. d dvd i}"
shows  "n 12 = Max (n ` {1..15})"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given a function $n$ that for each natural number $i$ between 1 and 15 inclusive, returns the number of divisors of $i$, what is the maximum value of $n(i)$ for $1 \leq i \leq 15$? The final answer is $n(12)$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes divisors :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "divisors n = {d. d dvd n}"
shows  "GREATEST n. n \<in> {1..15} \<and> card (divisors n) = Max ((\<lambda>n. card (divisors n)) ` {1..15}) = 12"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the numbers 1, 2, 3, ..., 15, which number has the greatest number of divisors (the dots mean that we are including all the integers between 1 and 15)? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 To find the number of divisors an integer has, we can count the number of positive divisors and double the result. For example, the positive divisors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4 while the set of all divisors of 4 is $\{-1,-2,-4,1,2,4\}$.
 So the number with the most divisors will be the same as the number with the most positive divisors.
 We can find the number of divisors of an integer by finding the divisors in pairs. For example, to find the divisors of 15, we begin by listing \[ 1, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, \ldots, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 15.
 \]Fifteen is not divisible by 2, so we skip to 3 and find $3\cdot 5 = 15$, so we fill in 3 and 5. Three and 5 are "buddies," since they multiply to give 15. Our list becomes \[ 1, 3, \underline{\hphantom{3}},\ldots \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 5, 15.
 \]Since 15 is not divisible by 4, we are done (since 5 is the next number and we already have 5 on the list).
 So the total list of divisors is \[ 1, 3, 5, 15. \]Since the numbers less than 15 are small, we can easily apply this process to all the numbers from 1 to 15. Here is a table showing how many factors each number has: \begin{tabular}{c|c}
 number & how many factors \\ \hline 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \\ 7 & 2 \\ 8 & 4 \\ 9 & 3 \\ 10 & 4 \\ 11 & 2 \\ 12 & 6 \\ 13 & 2 \\ 14 & 4 \\ 15 & 4 \end{tabular}We see that $\boxed{12}$ has the most factors.
 *)

theorem
fixes divisors :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "divisors n = {d. d dvd n}"
shows  "GREATEST n. n \<in> {1..15} \<and> card (divisors n) = Max ((\<lambda>n. card (divisors n)) ` {1..15}) = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the greatest natural number less than or equal to 15 that has the maximum number of divisors. The final answer is 12.

a_5.formal problem:
fun divisors :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set" where
"divisors n = {d. d dvd n}"

definition most_divisors :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> nat" where
"most_divisors N = Max (image (\<lambda>n. card (divisors n)) N)"

theorem
shows  "most_divisors {1..15} = 12"
end
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the numbers 1, 2, 3, ..., 15, which number has the greatest number of divisors (the dots mean that we are including all the integers between 1 and 15)? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 To find the number of divisors an integer has, we can count the number of positive divisors and double the result. For example, the positive divisors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4 while the set of all divisors of 4 is $\{-1,-2,-4,1,2,4\}$.
 So the number with the most divisors will be the same as the number with the most positive divisors.
 We can find the number of divisors of an integer by finding the divisors in pairs. For example, to find the divisors of 15, we begin by listing \[ 1, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, \ldots, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 15.
 \]Fifteen is not divisible by 2, so we skip to 3 and find $3\cdot 5 = 15$, so we fill in 3 and 5. Three and 5 are "buddies," since they multiply to give 15. Our list becomes \[ 1, 3, \underline{\hphantom{3}},\ldots \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 5, 15.
 \]Since 15 is not divisible by 4, we are done (since 5 is the next number and we already have 5 on the list).
 So the total list of divisors is \[ 1, 3, 5, 15. \]Since the numbers less than 15 are small, we can easily apply this process to all the numbers from 1 to 15. Here is a table showing how many factors each number has: \begin{tabular}{c|c}
 number & how many factors \\ \hline 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \\ 7 & 2 \\ 8 & 4 \\ 9 & 3 \\ 10 & 4 \\ 11 & 2 \\ 12 & 6 \\ 13 & 2 \\ 14 & 4 \\ 15 & 4 \end{tabular}We see that $\boxed{12}$ has the most factors.
 *)



fun divisors :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set" where
"divisors n = {d. d dvd n}"

definition most_divisors :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> nat" where
"most_divisors N = Max (image (\<lambda>n. card (divisors n)) N)"

theorem
shows  "most_divisors {1..15} = 12"
end
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Define a function that generates the set of all divisors of a given natural number. Then define a function that, for a given set of natural numbers, determines the maximum number of divisors that a number in the set has. What is the number with the most divisors in the set of natural numbers from 1 to 15? The final answer is 12.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 15 \<longrightarrow> f x = {d. d dvd x}"
shows  "Max (card ` range f) = 12"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the numbers 1, 2, 3, ..., 15, which number has the greatest number of divisors (the dots mean that we are including all the integers between 1 and 15)? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 To find the number of divisors an integer has, we can count the number of positive divisors and double the result. For example, the positive divisors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4 while the set of all divisors of 4 is $\{-1,-2,-4,1,2,4\}$.
 So the number with the most divisors will be the same as the number with the most positive divisors.
 We can find the number of divisors of an integer by finding the divisors in pairs. For example, to find the divisors of 15, we begin by listing \[ 1, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, \ldots, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 15.
 \]Fifteen is not divisible by 2, so we skip to 3 and find $3\cdot 5 = 15$, so we fill in 3 and 5. Three and 5 are "buddies," since they multiply to give 15. Our list becomes \[ 1, 3, \underline{\hphantom{3}},\ldots \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 5, 15.
 \]Since 15 is not divisible by 4, we are done (since 5 is the next number and we already have 5 on the list).
 So the total list of divisors is \[ 1, 3, 5, 15. \]Since the numbers less than 15 are small, we can easily apply this process to all the numbers from 1 to 15. Here is a table showing how many factors each number has: \begin{tabular}{c|c}
 number & how many factors \\ \hline 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \\ 7 & 2 \\ 8 & 4 \\ 9 & 3 \\ 10 & 4 \\ 11 & 2 \\ 12 & 6 \\ 13 & 2 \\ 14 & 4 \\ 15 & 4 \end{tabular}We see that $\boxed{12}$ has the most factors.
 *)

theorem 
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 15 \<longrightarrow> f x = {d. d dvd x}"
shows  "Max (card ` range f) = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: For every integer $x$ between 1 and 15 (inclusive), let $f(x)$ be the set of divisors of $x$. What is the maximum number of elements in these sets? The final answer is 12.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {1..15}"
shows  "Max {d. \<exists> k \<in> {1..15}. k dvd n} = 12"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the numbers 1, 2, 3, ..., 15, which number has the greatest number of divisors (the dots mean that we are including all the integers between 1 and 15)? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 To find the number of divisors an integer has, we can count the number of positive divisors and double the result. For example, the positive divisors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4 while the set of all divisors of 4 is $\{-1,-2,-4,1,2,4\}$.
 So the number with the most divisors will be the same as the number with the most positive divisors.
 We can find the number of divisors of an integer by finding the divisors in pairs. For example, to find the divisors of 15, we begin by listing \[ 1, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, \ldots, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 15.
 \]Fifteen is not divisible by 2, so we skip to 3 and find $3\cdot 5 = 15$, so we fill in 3 and 5. Three and 5 are "buddies," since they multiply to give 15. Our list becomes \[ 1, 3, \underline{\hphantom{3}},\ldots \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 5, 15.
 \]Since 15 is not divisible by 4, we are done (since 5 is the next number and we already have 5 on the list).
 So the total list of divisors is \[ 1, 3, 5, 15. \]Since the numbers less than 15 are small, we can easily apply this process to all the numbers from 1 to 15. Here is a table showing how many factors each number has: \begin{tabular}{c|c}
 number & how many factors \\ \hline 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \\ 7 & 2 \\ 8 & 4 \\ 9 & 3 \\ 10 & 4 \\ 11 & 2 \\ 12 & 6 \\ 13 & 2 \\ 14 & 4 \\ 15 & 4 \end{tabular}We see that $\boxed{12}$ has the most factors.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {1..15}"
shows  "Max {d. \<exists> k \<in> {1..15}. k dvd n} = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the maximum divisor of a natural number $n$ within the set {1,2,3,...,15}. The final answer is 12.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: nat
assumes h0 : "x ∈ {1..15}"
shows  "x = 12" if "\<forall>y ∈ {1..15}. card {z. z ≤ y ∧ y mod z = 0} ≤ card {z. z ≤ x ∧ x mod z = 0}" for x y z :: nat
using that by blast
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the numbers 1, 2, 3, ..., 15, which number has the greatest number of divisors (the dots mean that we are including all the integers between 1 and 15)? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 To find the number of divisors an integer has, we can count the number of positive divisors and double the result. For example, the positive divisors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4 while the set of all divisors of 4 is $\{-1,-2,-4,1,2,4\}$.
 So the number with the most divisors will be the same as the number with the most positive divisors.
 We can find the number of divisors of an integer by finding the divisors in pairs. For example, to find the divisors of 15, we begin by listing \[ 1, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, \ldots, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 15.
 \]Fifteen is not divisible by 2, so we skip to 3 and find $3\cdot 5 = 15$, so we fill in 3 and 5. Three and 5 are "buddies," since they multiply to give 15. Our list becomes \[ 1, 3, \underline{\hphantom{3}},\ldots \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 5, 15.
 \]Since 15 is not divisible by 4, we are done (since 5 is the next number and we already have 5 on the list).
 So the total list of divisors is \[ 1, 3, 5, 15. \]Since the numbers less than 15 are small, we can easily apply this process to all the numbers from 1 to 15. Here is a table showing how many factors each number has: \begin{tabular}{c|c}
 number & how many factors \\ \hline 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \\ 7 & 2 \\ 8 & 4 \\ 9 & 3 \\ 10 & 4 \\ 11 & 2 \\ 12 & 6 \\ 13 & 2 \\ 14 & 4 \\ 15 & 4 \end{tabular}We see that $\boxed{12}$ has the most factors.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: nat
assumes h0 : "x ∈ {1..15}"
shows  "x = 12" if "\<forall>y ∈ {1..15}. card {z. z ≤ y ∧ y mod z = 0} ≤ card {z. z ≤ x ∧ x mod z = 0}" for x y z :: nat
using that by blast
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find a natural number $x$ between 1 and 15 such that it has more or equal number of divisors than any other number in the same range. The final answer is $12$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes divisors :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. divisors n = {d. d \<le> n \<and> n mod d = 0}"
shows  "Max {card (divisors n) | n. n \<in> {1..15}} = 12"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the numbers 1, 2, 3, ..., 15, which number has the greatest number of divisors (the dots mean that we are including all the integers between 1 and 15)? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 To find the number of divisors an integer has, we can count the number of positive divisors and double the result. For example, the positive divisors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4 while the set of all divisors of 4 is $\{-1,-2,-4,1,2,4\}$.
 So the number with the most divisors will be the same as the number with the most positive divisors.
 We can find the number of divisors of an integer by finding the divisors in pairs. For example, to find the divisors of 15, we begin by listing \[ 1, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, \ldots, \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 15.
 \]Fifteen is not divisible by 2, so we skip to 3 and find $3\cdot 5 = 15$, so we fill in 3 and 5. Three and 5 are "buddies," since they multiply to give 15. Our list becomes \[ 1, 3, \underline{\hphantom{3}},\ldots \underline{\hphantom{3}}, 5, 15.
 \]Since 15 is not divisible by 4, we are done (since 5 is the next number and we already have 5 on the list).
 So the total list of divisors is \[ 1, 3, 5, 15. \]Since the numbers less than 15 are small, we can easily apply this process to all the numbers from 1 to 15. Here is a table showing how many factors each number has: \begin{tabular}{c|c}
 number & how many factors \\ \hline 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \\ 7 & 2 \\ 8 & 4 \\ 9 & 3 \\ 10 & 4 \\ 11 & 2 \\ 12 & 6 \\ 13 & 2 \\ 14 & 4 \\ 15 & 4 \end{tabular}We see that $\boxed{12}$ has the most factors.
 *)

theorem
fixes divisors :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. divisors n = {d. d \<le> n \<and> n mod d = 0}"
shows  "Max {card (divisors n) | n. n \<in> {1..15}} = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: What is the maximum number of divisors that a number from 1 to 15 has? The final answer is 12.
